site.title: One Breath Partnership
site.description: One Breath Partnership elevates the work for clean air for everyone in Houston, Harris County and Texas.
site.home_header: Working for clean air every day for everyone.

mainImage.alt: Efram Jernigan has big visions for the health and wealth of the neighborhood where he grew up. Photo: Leah Binkovitz.
mainImage.caption: Efram Jernigan has big visions for the health and wealth of the neighborhood where he grew up. Photo: Leah Binkovitz.

node.title: In Houston's Sunnyside, overburdened from decades of discrimination, you learn to provide for yourself

children.text: Residents are writing a 'new narrative' of clean energy, health and fresh food from within a community once recklessly dumped on by the city that annexed it.

node.Action1Title: Get involved with the Sunnyside Community Redevelopment Organization

mainImage.alt: Rep. Ann Johnson defeated incumbent Sarah Davis in November 2020 to represent Texas House District 134 in Houston.
mainImage.caption: Rep. Ann Johnson defeated incumbent Sarah Davis in November 2020 to represent Texas House District 134 in Houston.

node.title: 'There is nothing more important than air quality': A conversation with Rep. Ann Johnson

children.text: Newly elected to represent House District 134, Ann Johnson sees the 87th state legislative session as an opportunity to 'put some strength back into the regulations' that will protect Texans' health.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about one dirty power plant's contribution to poor air quality in Texas

mainImage.alt: Researchers at Rice University found that Parish’s PM 2.5 likely contributes to as many as 178 premature deaths each year in the region.
mainImage.caption: Researchers at Rice University found that Parish’s PM 2.5 likely contributes to as many as 178 premature deaths each year in the region.

node.title: The W. A. Parish plant is burning your lungs and the planet. Why won’t NRG replace it?

children.text: NRG's CEO has said he wants the company to help Houston transition to clean energy, but researchers found the coal-fired plant is responsible for more carbon dioxide than the entire state of Delaware.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about the sources and harms of sulfur dioxide

mainImage.alt: Hurricane Laura ripped the roof of this home in Lake Charles. Photo: 2C2K Photography, modified under CC BY 2.0.
mainImage.caption: Hurricane Laura ripped the roof of this home in Lake Charles. Photo: 2C2K Photography, modified under CC BY 2.0.

node.title: Louisiana has been battered this hurricane season. Will the attention last as long as the recovery takes?

children.text: The lack of attention given to Louisiana residents struggling with disaster recovery mirrors the larger indifference about environmental justice communities along the industrial Gulf Coast.

node.Action1Title: Donate to the Mutual Aid Response Network to help with relief and recovery

mainImage.alt: The W. A. Parish plant near Houston is the second-largest source of sulfur dioxide in Texas. Photo: Allyn West.
mainImage.caption: The W. A. Parish plant near Houston is the second-largest source of sulfur dioxide in Texas. Photo: Allyn West.

children.text: Burning fossil fuels produces this gas that can lead to acid rain and make breathing difficult, especially for children and people with asthma.

mainImage.alt: Hurricane Laura made landfall in Louisiana as a high-end Category 4 storm, with winds up to 150 mph. Photo: Julie Dermansky.
mainImage.caption: Hurricane Laura made landfall in Louisiana as a high-end Category 4 storm, with winds up to 150 mph. Photo: Julie Dermansky.

node.title: The communities who need it most aren't receiving air quality information during disasters like Hurricane Laura

children.text: More needs to be done to monitor air quality and inform communities at risk of exposure to industrial pollution during hurricanes.

node.Action1Title: Read the EPA's report on the need for better planning with air quality monitoring during disasters

mainImage.alt: Most people never experience industrial degradation beyond what they read or see on the news or from behind the window of a passing car, but we owe it to each other to pay attention.
mainImage.caption: Most people never experience industrial degradation beyond what they read or see on the news or from behind the window of a passing car, but we owe it to each other to pay attention.

node.title: The Gulf Coast is our backyard. We can’t let polluters threaten our health.

children.text: Most people never experience industrial degradation beyond what they read or see on the news or from behind the window of a passing car, but we owe it to each other to pay attention.

node.title: Increased production of plastics is increasing risks for Port Arthur residents during the pandemic

children.text: Port Arthur residents are breathing air filled with more emissions from the increased demand and production of personal protective equipment.

mainImage.caption: The state environmental agency sued the attorney general to keep documents and emails about weaker protections for a cancer-causing chemical confidential.

node.title: Why won't TCEQ explain why it weakened protections for a cancer-causing chemical?

children.text: The state environmental agency sued the state attorney general to keep confidential the documents and emails about its decision to weaken protections for a cancer-causing chemical.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about TCEQ's and Honeycutt's history
